title: Minimum size of the Field-Corner Gift
vignette: A land-owner has harvested most of his wheat and must now set aside a corner for the poor. May he leave the bare legal minimum (1⁄60) or is he expected to be more generous?

options.text: Give only 1⁄60 — owner may keep the rest.
Give a larger share, based on field size and local need.

title: Early vs. late designation of Field-Corner Gift
vignette: The owner has already left some standing stalks at the field’s start but nothing at the end. Count those early stalks as the poor’s share or treat them as ownerless property for anyone to take?

options.text: Count them as field-corner gift reserved for the poor (a specific wise person).
Treat them as ownerless property; even the rich may take (another specific wise person).

title: Who gathers dangerous high fruit?
vignette: Dates hang high in a palm grove. Should the owner climb, cut the clusters and distribute them, or must the poor climb and pick for themselves?

options.text: Owner must harvest and hand out — safety first.
Let the poor harvest individually; owner needn’t intervene.

title: Grabbing all the gleanings
vignette: One pauper spreads his cloak over an un-collected pile to reserve everything for himself.

options.text: Let him keep what he covered — first come, first served.
Confiscate the pile and redistribute fairly (collection of oral traditions ruling).

title: Scythes in the scramble
vignette: May the poor cut field-corner gift with sickles and spades, risking injury to one another?

options.text: Permit any tools; faster harvest for all.
Ban sharp tools; prevent harm among the poor.

title: How often may the poor enter a field?
vignette: Local leaders fix three daily collection times. Some poor people want free access all day.

options.text: Limit to three visits; prevents crowding and conflict (a leading wise person).
Allow continuous entry; maximise the poor’s opportunity (yet another specific wise person).

title: New Community Member who harvested before joining the community
vignette: A non-member reaps his field, then converts to community membership before bundling. Must he now leave sheaves for the poor?

options.text: Exempt — the reaping happened while he was a non-member (the first opinion holder).
Obligate for the forgotten sheaf; duty attaches at binding (another specific wise person).

title: Central Assembly Place-dedicated crop later exchanged
vignette: Grain was declared central assembly place property and later exchanged by the owner. Are poor-people gifts still required?

options.text: Yes — after exchange, normal obligations resume.
No — at the crucial stage the grain belonged to the central assembly place and was exempt.

title: Setting Field-Corner Gift aside for a named pauper
vignette: A volunteer harvests field-corner gift and says, “This is for community assistant the pauper.” Does community assistant acquire ownership automatically?

options.text: Yes — the collector acquires it on community assistant’s behalf (still another specific wise person).
No — must give to the first poor person encountered (wise people).

title: Ownerless property for poor only, or for everyone?
vignette: A farmer declares his crop ‘ownerless property for the poor.’ Is that valid, or must ownerless property include the rich as well?

options.text: Valid — a partial ownerless property in favour of the poor works (school of Shammai).
Invalid — ownerless property must be equal-access, rich or poor (school of Hillel).

title: Oversized forgotten sheaf
vignette: All sheaves are one unit of volume except one four-unit of volume sheaf left behind. Does it count as ‘forgotten’ for the poor?

options.text: Not forgotten — owner keeps it (school of Shammai).
Forgotten — poor may take it (school of Hillel).

title: Sheaf left near obvious landmarks
vignette: A sheaf is left beside a stone wall or farm tools. Is it considered forgotten?

options.text: Not forgotten — owner intended to return (school of Shammai).
Forgotten — poor may take it (school of Hillel).

title: ‘Two or three’ rule for small bundles
vignette: How many forgotten sheaves, berries or flax-stalks trigger the poor’s right?

options.text: Two belong to the poor; three revert to owner (school of Hillel).
Three to poor; four to owner (school of Shammai).

title: Two small sheaves totalling a full measure
vignette: Two forgotten bundles together equal two larger unit of volume (a full stack). Who owns them?

options.text: Owner keeps them (a leading wise person).
Poor take them (wise people).

title: Scattered plots between olive trees
vignette: Small wheat plots lie between rows of olives. Leave one corner from each tiny plot or treat the whole area as one field?

options.text: Give field-corner gift from every plot (school of Shammai).
One field-corner gift for them all (school of Hillel).

title: Striped harvesting pattern
vignette: Farmer mows the field in stripes, leaving moist stalks between. Does each moist patch need its own field-corner gift?

options.text: Yes; each stripe counts separately (yet another specific wise person).
No; one field-corner gift satisfies the lot (wise people).

title: Harvesting fresh onions vs. storing dry
vignette: Owner pulls fresh onions to sell now but leaves the rest to dry for storage. Is field-corner gift required twice?

options.text: Two separate field-corner gifts – each harvest is distinct.
Single field-corner gift on the final remainder.

title: Seed-onion exemption
vignette: Are seed-onions liable to field-corner gift, and does an onion plot between vegetables need field-corner gift for each sub-plot?

options.text: Liable; each onion patch must give (wise people).
Exempt; or only one combined field-corner gift (one more specific wise person).

title: Brothers divide then re-partner
vignette: Two brothers split the inherited field. Do they each leave field-corner gift separately? Later they farm together again—now what?

options.text: After division, each must give; after re-partnership, just one field-corner gift.
Always one field-corner gift—treat estate continuity as overriding.

title: Minimum plot size liable for Field-Corner Gift
vignette: How small can a field be yet still owe a corner to the poor? Measures range from ‘six by six small units of length’ to ‘any size’.

options.text: Only sizeable plots (various larger minima).
Even the tiniest patch is liable (yet another specific wise person).

title: Gleaning stalk mixed into owner’s pile
vignette: A gleaning stalk falls into the harvest pile. May the owner swap in another stalk (after setting aside a portion) or must he hand over the original?

options.text: Swap permitted—owner keeps his pile (still another specific wise person).
No swap—return the very stalk to the poor (wise people).
